awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: CICNet - The One-Rutgers Next Generation Data Driven Research Network
awd_abstract_narration:
CICNet, the One-Rutgers Next Generation Data Driven Research Network, supports the need of an increasingly diverse research community to access distributed data, cloud environments, advanced computing resources and other research instruments, including Sequencers, MRIs, Sensor Arrays, Electron Microscopes, and Radio Telescopes. The overarching goal of this project is to improve the productivity of the research community by removing bottlenecks associated with the movement of data not only between campuses, but with the national cyberinfrastructure ecosystem, including XSEDE, Open Science Grid, Pacific Research Platform, CloudLab, and GENI. With CICNet, Rutgers attempts to create a transformative research environment where central IT and the research community are partners and collaborators.

CICNet evolves under this project to a 40Gbps research and education campus network across Rutgers, with a 100Gbps ScienceDMZ and 100Gbps connectivity to Internet2. CICNet is a research network that is also available as a research project. The partnership between central IT with the research community, including GENI/OpenFlow/SDN researchers, is designed as a model for integrating new network technologies into an existing framework, creating a path for future use both at Rutgers and beyond. The integration of OpenFlow with high performance computing, distributed across multiple campuses (Camden, Newark, and New Brunswick/Piscataway) is an innovative extension that Rutgers does not have in place today. Outreach and training led by the IT staff deploying CICNet and the Rutgers Wireless Research Group, WINLAB, extends the current relationship between both IT and the research and education communities. The completed network upgrade is designed to support significant new scientific research and education opportunities for multiple departments, colleges, and research groups across all Rutgers campuses that require access to remote instruments and/or transfer large datasets.

por.por_cntn:
Access to distributed data, cloud environments, advanced computing resources and other research instruments (e.g., Sequencers, MRIs, Sensor Arrays, Electron Microscopes, and Radio Telescopes) has become increasingly crucial to research and education endeavors in a wide range of disciplines. While campus IT groups around the nation continue to invest in production level enterprise-class high-speed network infrastructure and services, provisioning very high bandwidth end-to-end connectivity across and beyond campus networks today becomes a major undertaking. What makes this even more interesting for is that Rutgers University is comprised of three campuses located throughout New Jersey ? Newark, New Brunswick/Piscataway, and Camden ? each with its own set of challenges. The Office of Advanced Research Computing (OARC) was founded in 2016 with a mission to support research across all campuses, including medical, through research computing, data services, and advanced networking solutions. To achieve the goals of this mission, OARC invested in building infrastructure on each of the campuses. The real challenge came when trying to connect each of the campuses data centers through a high speed low-latency network in order to enable cross campus research collaborations, especially those requiring access to large amounts of data.

This project addressed this challenge by building the Cyberinfrastructure Core Network (CICNet), a ?One Rutgers? data driven friction-less research network, connecting all campuses, to enable productive research and education with next generation network services. Utilizing the funding provided by this award as well as contributions from the University?s Office of Information Technology (OIT) and Office of Advanced Research Computing (OARC), Rutgers updated its current research network by implementing Software Defined Network (SDN) based connections across and between campuses. This next generation research network, called CICNet, allowed us to build distributed federated research computing resources and data repositories across the Rutgers campuses (Camden, Newark, and New Brunswick/Piscataway) that improved the speed (100 Gbps) and QoS between these campuses as well as to the national cyberinfrastructure ecosystem, e.g., XSEDE, Open Science Grid (OSG), COSMOS, Pacific Research Platform (PRP), CloudLab, and GENI.

The Intellectual Merit of CICNet was not only to deploy a highspeed low latency programable network to support research collaborations requiring data intensive workflows but was also designed to be available to those interested in doing network research. The partnership formed during this project between campus research IT staff and the research community has become a model for other campuses integrating new network technologies into existing frameworks, e.g. several institutions within the Eastern Regional Network see the research platform developed through CICNet as a model for future platforms. The integration of OpenFlow or other SDN solutions with high performance computing clusters and data solutions distributed across three campuses are novel extensions of capabilities that were not in place before the project started. The outreach and routine support by the IT staff deploying CICNet stretched traditional support models for both IT and the research and education communities. The completed network upgrade now supports significant new scientific research and education initiatives for multiple departments, colleges, and research groups across all Rutgers campuses, not just the research groups listed in the proposal, that required access to remote instruments and/or transfer large datasets. For this reason, we have seen that both funded and developing research initiatives benefited from this upgrade.

The Broader Impacts of CICNet impacted at least four major areas: science discovery, infrastructure, technology transfer, and workforce training. Science Discovery: Although the science and research applications described in this proposal were the immediate beneficiaries of CICNet, the benefits of this network affected the campus community as a whole, allowing researchers at Rutgers to connect their instruments directly to the CICNet research platform leading to new discoveries. Infrastructure: This project is a catalyst for future advances and upgrades to Rutgers?s networking infrastructure and its ability to connect to the national infrastructure. The SDN is designed to be sustainable through the support of central IT, as it will be a part of Rutgers?s production/supported network infrastructure. Technology Transfer: We shared best practices with communities that are planning similar network upgrades within a distributed environment. This project has the potential of becoming a national model as campuses across the nation are figuring out how to share. Workforce Training: Our outreach, education, and training efforts activities led by OARC and WINLAB are designed to engage faculty, students, and the IT staff across all campuses.
